RT @XFreeze: ELON MUSK: MAKE LIFE MULTI-PLANETARY WITH THE KEY THRESHOLD TO SUSTAIN EVEN WITHOUT SUPPLY SHIPS FROM EARTH

"The goal is to m‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
ELON MUSK: MAKE LIFE MULTI-PLANETARY WITH THE KEY THRESHOLD TO SUSTAIN EVEN WITHOUT SUPPLY SHIPS FROM EARTH

"The goal is to make life multi-planetary. The key threshold for that is if the supply ships from Earth stop coming for any reason, Mars does not die out

That is the critical "Great Filter," if you talk about things in terms of the Fermi Paradox

"The Great Filter is Mars being self-sustaining without any supply ships from Earth"

Until we reach that point, we are really just a one-planet civilization with an extension. If Mars becomes self-sustaining, then even in a worst-case scenario of Earth‚Äôs civilization either dying with a bang or a whimper Mars would have a much better chance of surviving

So, the intent here overall is to ensure that the light of consciousness, which appears to be just a tiny candle in a vast darkness"

tweets.text:
RT @teslaownersSV: WHY WE SHOULD GO TO MARS: ELON MUSK ON SECURING THE FUTURE OF CONSCIOUSNESS
Going to Mars isn‚Äôt about escape‚Äîit‚Äôs about‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
WHY WE SHOULD GO TO MARS: ELON MUSK ON SECURING THE FUTURE OF CONSCIOUSNESS
Going to Mars isn‚Äôt about escape‚Äîit‚Äôs about insurance. It‚Äôs about making sure the light of consciousness doesn‚Äôt go out if something catastrophic happens on Earth. Elon has consistently framed the Mars mission as the single most important step humanity can take to ensure long-term survival and expansion.

‚ÄúThe key branching point for human destiny or destiny of consciousness as a whole is that Mars is self-sustaining, even if the resupply ships from Earth stop coming. You‚Äôre not multiplanetary until the planet can grow by itself. Because there‚Äôs always some risk of technology on Earth falling below a certain level or of a nuclear war or a meteor. You haven‚Äôt secured the future of civilization and consciousness until both planets can survive independently.‚Äù

This is why Mars matters:
‚Ä¢  Backup for humanity ‚Äî A second home protects against single-point failures (asteroids, supervolcanoes, pandemics, nuclear conflict, AI misalignment, etc.).
‚Ä¢  Self-sustaining civilization ‚Äî Once Mars can grow its own population and industry without constant Earth resupply, consciousness becomes multiplanetary and far more resilient.
‚Ä¢  Inspiration & progress driver ‚Äî The challenge forces breakthroughs in energy, life support, materials, AI, and closed-loop systems that benefit Earth too.
‚Ä¢  Long-term species survival ‚Äî Staying on one fragile planet forever is a gamble with extinction-level risks. Mars turns that into a hedge.

Every Starship launch, every refueling test, every iteration brings us closer to that branching point. It‚Äôs not luxury‚Äîit‚Äôs the ultimate act of responsibility toward future generations.
